{{Music of Canada}}
'''Canadian rock''' describes a wide and diverse variety of [[Music of Canada|music produced]] by [[Canadians]], beginning with [[United States|American]] style [[rock and roll|rock 'n' roll]] in the mid-20th century.<ref>Top Pop Records 1940-1955 Author Joel Whitburn Publisher Record Research Billboard year 1973 p. 211. (ISBN 089820092)</ref> Since then Canada has had a considerable impact on the development of the modern [[popular music]] called [[rock music|rock]].<ref name="canrock" /><ref name="heart" /><ref name="gold" /> Canada has produced many of the genre's most significant groups and performers, while contributing substantively to the development of the most popular [[Canadian music genres|sub-genres]], which include [[pop rock]], [[progressive rock]], [[country rock]], [[folk rock]], [[hard rock]], [[punk rock]], [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] and [[indie rock]].<ref name="CHUM">{{cite book|title=The CHUM chart book from 1957 to 1986 |isbn=09-20325-157|author=Ron Hall |publisher=Stardust Productions (Toronto, Ont.)Canada|year=1990}}</ref><ref name="billboard">{{cite book|title=The Billboard Book of Hits |isbn=0-8230-8285-7|author=Adam White & Fred Bronson|publisher=Billboard Books|year=1988}}</ref><ref name="RPM">{{cite web |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/index-e.html |title=RPM (magazine)collection at Library and Archives Canada |work=RPM Awards |accessdate=2010-02-10}}Requires running a searches for Artist or year</ref><ref>ENCYCLOPEDIA OF CANADIAN ROCK, POP, AND FOLK MUSIC / by Rick Jackson. Kingston, Ont. : Quarry Press, 1994. 319 p. (Ref ML102 .P66 J13 1994t)</ref>

Cambridge, Ont.|publisher= Habitex Books|year= 1975 |page= 320|isbn=088912020X}}</ref><ref name="Mich" >{{cite book |title=La Musique au QuÃ©bec 1600-1875|work= by Michelle Pharand|publisher= Montreal - Les Ãditions de l'Homme |year=1976|isbn=0775905178}}</ref> From the 17th century onward Canada has developed a music infrastructure, that includes [[concert hall]]s, [[conservatories]], [[academies]], [[performing arts centre]]s, [[Record company|record companies]], [[radio stations]] and national [[music video]] television channels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.broadcasting-history.ca/timeline/CCFTimeline.html |title=Broadcasting Stations in Canada |work=The Canadian Communications Foundation|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> The success of the [[Gramophone record|gramophone]] at the beginning of the 20th century allowed Canadian songwriters to broaden their potential audiences.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=U1ARTU0000658 |title=Chamber music performance|work=Encyclopedia of Music in Canada |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref><ref name="1930s and 1940s" >Canadian Music in the 1930s and 1940s. by Beverley Cavanagh. ===The beginning of Canadian rock 1950s=== {{See also|Canadian blues}}
'''Rock 'n' roll''' arose in the [[United States]] in the late 1940s<ref>Jim Dawson and Steve Propes, What Was The First Rock'n'Roll Record, 1992, ISBN 0-571-12939-0 1 Jazz at the Philharmonic: Blues, Part 2 (1944) 2 Joe Liggins: The Honeydripper (1945) 3 Helen Humes: Be-Baba-Leba (1945) 4 Freddie Slack: House Of Blue Lights (1946)</ref><ref>Farley, Christopher John, [http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,661084,00.html Elvis Presley's July 5th, 1954 recording of Thats All Right, a cover of a song previously released by its composer, bluesman Arthur Big Boy Crudup, in 1946.], July 06, 2004</ref> after [[World War II]], from a combination of the rhythms of [[African American music|African American]] [[blues]], country<ref>Peterson, Richard A. (1999). ''Creating Country Music: Fabricating Authenticity'', p.9. ISBN 0-226-66285-3.</ref> and [[gospel music]].<ref>Christ-Janer, Albert, Charles W. Hughes, and Carleton Sprague Smith. ''American Hymns Old and New''. New York: Columbia University Press, 1980. p. 364. ISBN 0-231-03458-X</ref> Though elements of rock and roll can be heard in Canadian country records of the 1930s-1940s, and in American blues records from the 1920s,<ref>Davis, Francis. ''The History of the Blues''. New York: Hyperion, 1995, ISBN 0-7868-8124-0)</ref> rock and roll did not acquire its name until the 1950s.<ref>{{cite album-notes |title=The Roots of Rock 'n' Roll 1946-1954 "Anthologize the recordings of the late '40s and early '50s most crucial to planting the seeds for rock & roll" |publisher=Universal Music |Date=April 13, 2004 |format=CD Hip-O Records}}</ref><ref>Dawson, Jim & Propes, Steve, ''What was the first rock ânâ roll record?'', Faber & Faber, ISBN 0-571-12939-0, 1992</ref> "Rock"' or its forerunners [[electric blues]] ([[Chicago blues]])<ref>{{cite album-notes |title=Detroit Ghetto Blues 1948 to 1954 |last=Pierson |first=Leroy |publisher=[[Nighthawk Records]] |publisherid=104 |date=1976 |location=St. Louis |format=Vynil back cover |url=http://www.wirz.de/music/nighthaw/grafik/104b4.jpg |accessdate=2010-02-10 }} </ref> and [[rhythm and blues]] ([[Jump blues]])<ref>{{cite web |title=ROCK BEFORE ELVIS [[Good Rockin' Tonight]] [[Wynonie Harris]] (recorded on December 28, 1947)Jump blues!| url=http://www.hoyhoy.com/dawn_of_rock.htm |work= ROCK BEFORE ELVIS www.hoyhoy.com|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> was first heard in the late 1940s by Canadians who were living close enough to the American border to tune in to American radio station broadcasts.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cohn|first=Lawrence|title=Nothing but the Blues: The Music and the Musicians|coauthors=Aldin,Mary Katherine; Bastin,Bruce|publisher=Abbeville Press|pages=314 ISBN 1-55859-271-7|isbn=978-1558592711|year=1993|month=September }}</ref> [[File:PaulAnka07.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Paul Anka]], 2007|alt=Color bust photo of a man in a tuxedo, holding a microphone.]] In 1951, [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] [[disc jockey]] [[Alan Freed]] began playing rhythm and blues music for a multi-racial audience, and is credited with first using the phrase "rock and roll" to describe the musical sound of the [[Doo-wop|Doo-wop vocal groups]] and the [[rockabilly]] singers who emerged in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite book |title=Music USA By Richie Unterberger, Samb Hicks, Jennifer Dempsey |url=http://books.google.com/?id=uwtAx1xP9BMC&lpg=PA282&dq=rock%20and%20roll%20alan%20freed&pg=PA282#v=onepage&q= |isbn=9781858284217 |author1=Unterberger, Richie |author2=Hicks, Samb |author3=Dempsey, Jennifer |date=1999-06-21}}ISBN 1-85828-421-X. Retrieved 2010-02-10</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://books.google.com/?id=rBjdP_rGpacC&lpg=PA63&dq=rock%20and%20roll%20alan%20freed&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q= |title=American Popular Music: The age of rock By Timothy E. Scheurer |isbn=9780879724689 |author1=Scheurer, Timothy E |year=1989 }}ISBN 978-0-87972-467-2 Retrieved 2010-02-10</ref> [[The Four Lads]], from [[Toronto]], were one of the first groups to capitalize on this sound and become a prominent act in the Canadian rhythm and blues scene, producing their first hit in 1952 called "[[The Mocking Bird|Mocking Bird]]". Their most famous hit was "[[Moments to Remember]]", which first reached the Billboard magazine charts on September 3, 1955.<ref name="billboard" /> Emerging in the mid 1950s, on near equal-footing to [[American popular music]], Canadian popular music enjoyed considerable success at home and abroad.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://indierockmemories.com/PlayingCanadian.html|title=Canadian music, 1950-present|accessdate=2010-02-10 }}</ref>
1954 the name "rock and roll" had become the common name of the popular music of the day.<ref>{{cite web | title = Rock and roll Date:1954| work = Merriam-Webster's Online Dictionary | publisher = Merriam-Webster Online | url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rock%20and%20roll |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> Rhythm and blues (R&B coined in 1949<ref>{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Robert|authorlink=Robert Palmer (author/producer)|title=Deep Blues: A Musical and Cultural History of the Mississippi Delta|date=1982-07-29|publisher=Penguin|edition=paperback|isbn=978-0140062236|pages=146|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref>) was too broad a term, because R&B was a category that included most forms of [[race music]], which generally had adult-based lyrics.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_g1epc/is_tov/ai_2419101005/ |work= St. James Encyclopedia of Pop Culture by Matthew A. Killmeier 01/29/02 |title= "race music" and "race records" were terms used to categorize practically all types of African-American music in the 1940s |accessdate=2010-02-10 | year=2002}}</ref> [[Crew-Cuts|The Crew-Cuts]], [[The Diamonds]]<ref>{{cite web | title= VocalGroup Hall of Fame inductees | work=vocalgroup.org|url=http://www.vocalgroup.org/inductees.htm|accessdate=2006-11-26}}</ref> and The Four Lads would emerge from this new marketing of rhythm and blues to appeal to a white audience leaving an indelible mark on the Doo-wop days.<ref name="Doo-Wop">{{cite web | title= The Doo-Wop Hall of Fame Inductees| work=doowophof.com|url=http://www.harveyrobbins.net/id2.htm|accessdate=2007-08-18}}</ref> Often Canadian records of this period were simply [[cover version|covers]] of pop hits, and rhythm and blues oldies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.silver-dragon-records.com/history_of_rock_and_roll.htm |title=Rock and Roll - The birth of rock music "White performers began to be hired to record and play the songs often doing a poor job. Still the music began to take hold with fans as white owned stations began to play the music"|work= by: Lazarus X - Silver Dragon Records 2003|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Pioneers of Canadian rock | work = CanConRox | publisher = Canadianbands.com| url = http://www.canadianbands.com/bios_1.html|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> 1958 saw Canada produced its first rock and roll [[teen idol]] [[Paul Anka]], who went to [[New York City]] where he auditioned for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] with the song, [[Diana (song)|Diana]]. This song brought Anka instant stardom and he became the first Canadian to have a number one on the US Billboard charts in the rock and roll era.<ref name="billboard" /> "Diana" is one of the best selling 45s in music history.<ref name="RIAA" /> He followed up with four songs that made it into the Top 20 in 1958, making him one of the biggest teen idols of the time.<ref name="gold" />
Most Canadians with successful recording careers in the 1950s had moved to the US, where the population level and media exposure would eclipse that of Canada.<ref>{{cite book | title= On a Cold Road: Tales of Adventure in Canadian Rock| work = By Dave Bidini. McClelland & Stewart, 1998. p.278 ISBN 0-7710-1456-2|url= http://books.google.com/?id=ll9wqMEWT4wC&dq=On+A+Cold+Road:+Tales+Of+Adventure+In+Canadian+Rock&printsec=frontcover|accessdate=2010-02-10 | isbn= 9780771014567 | author1= Bidini, Dave | date= 1998-10-01}}</ref> [[Ronnie Hawkins]], an [[Arkansas]] born rockabilly singer, moved to Canada in 1958, becoming a prominent figure in [[Canadian blues]] and rock devoting his life to popularizing Canadian musicians.<ref>{{cite web | title= Rockabilly Hall of Fame inductees| work=rockabillyhall.com|url=http://www.rockabillyhall.com/home.html|accessdate=2006-11-26}}</ref> He formed a backing band called [[The Hawks]], which produced some of the earliest Canadian rock stars. Among them were the members of [[The Band]], who began touring with [[Bob Dylan]] in 1966, and then struck out on their own in 1968.<ref>{{cite press release| title =Ronnie Hawkins 1958-2005| publisher =The Hamilton Spectator- Souvenir Edition |page= MP43| date =June 10, 2006| accessdate = 2007-01-29}}</ref>
===1960s=== [[File:Bruce Cockburn 2007.jpg|right|220px|thumb|[[Bruce Cockburn]] performing at the City Stages festival in Birmingham, Alabama, United States.]] As the late fifties gave way to the sixties, stars of the previous decade were still producing hits, but they were quickly losing ground as they struggled to find material that would click with this new and energetic generation.<ref name="gold" >Before the gold rush: flashbacks to the dawn of the Canadian sound by Nicholas Jennings, (Yorkville Ont) (ISBN 0-670-87381-0)</ref> The first [[Country of origin|Canadian-made]] and produced rock recording to achieve international popularity was "Clap Your Hands" in 1960 by a Montreal [[quartet]], [[The Beaumarks]].<ref>[http://peltonator.spaces.live.com/blog/cns!184A2363AD187F54!3935.entry?sa=362033914 CANADIAN Music Part 6: Homemade Rock (Early 60s)]. All music guide. Retrieved 2010-02-10</ref> Shortly thereafter, they appeared on ''[[American Bandstand]]'' and a charity concert at [[Carnegie Hall]].<ref>[http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=U1ARTU0004064 The BeauMarks] at The Canadian Encyclopedia. Retrieved 2010-02-10</ref> [[Bobby Curtola]] from [[Port Arthur, Ontario]] had several songs on the Canadian music charts beginning with "Hand In Hand With You" in 1960.<ref name="CHUM" /> His biggest [[chart-topper]] came in 1962 with the song, "Fortune Teller", which was also successful internationally.<ref name="Axes" /> In 1966, he won an [[Juno Award|RPM Gold Leaf Award]] (''The Gold Leaf Awards, which were in effect the first Juno Awards'') for being the first Canadian to have a [[gold album]].<ref>{{cite web | title= RPM Gold Leaf Award/Canadian Music Hall of Fame winner and nominations| work=juno-awards.ca|url=http://www.juno-awards.ca|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> The [[CHUM Chart]] debuted on May 27, 1957, under the name CHUM's Weekly Hit Parade, to 1986, and was the longest-running Top 40 chart in Canada.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestar.com/article/217451 |title=Happy 50th birthday old CHUM |work=Toronto Star May 26, 2007|accessdate=2010-02-10 | first=Greg | last=Quill | date=2007-05-26}}</ref>
During the 1960s Canadian music was regarded with indifference and Canadian recording artists were forced to turn toward the United States to establish their careers.<ref>The CHUM Story by Allen Farrell, Stoddart Publishing, 2001 (ISBN 0-7737-6263-9)</ref> In 1960 [[Walt Grealis]] of Toronto started in the music business with [[Apex Records]], the Ontario distributor for [[Compo Company]] (founded in 1918<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.capsnews.org/barrcom.htm |title=The Compo Company, History of Recorded Sound in Canada |work=Canadian Antique Phonograph Society |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref>), Canada's first independent record company that today is part of [[Universal Music Group|Universal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=U1ARTU0000771 |title=Compo Company Ltd. |work=The Canadian Encyclopedia (Historica Foundation of Canada)|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref><ref>{{ cite web |url=http://www.capsnews.org/barrcan.htm |work=Canadian Antique Phonograph Society |title=History of Recorded Sound in Canada|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> He later joined [[London Records]], where he worked until February 1964, when he then established [[RPM (magazine)|RPM weekly trade magazine]]. From the first issue of RPM Weekly on February 24, 1964 to its final issue on November 13, 2000, RPM was the defining charts in Canada.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/index-e.html?PHPSESSID=hcpqabrflcj0j327o3unbt23d7 |title=RPM 1964-2000 The Conscience of Canada's Music Industry |work=Library and Archives Canada -RPM history|accessdate=2010-02-10 }}</ref> The popularity of US rock on the two Canadian charts led to many existing groups, especially those devoted to country music, to change styles or to incorporate some rock style hits in their repertoires.<ref name="canrock" />[[File:Para Rael99 (que nos quiten lo bailao).jpg|left|200px|thumb| Neil Young.|alt=Black-and-white photo of a man playing the piano, there is a dink on the piano.]] Country rock and folk rock singers like [[Gordon Lightfoot]], [[Joni Mitchell]], [[Leonard Cohen]], [[Denny Doherty]] (of [[The Mamas & the Papas]]), [[David Clayton-Thomas]] (of [[Blood, Sweat & Tears]]), [[Andy Kim]], [[Zal Yanovsky]] (of [[The Lovin' Spoonful]]), [[John Kay (musician)|John Kay]] (of [[Steppenwolf (band)|Steppenwolf]]), and [[Ian & Sylvia]] found international audiences.<ref name="canrock" /> One important example was a [[Winnipeg]] band called [[Chad Allan (musician)|Chad Allan]] & the Expressions, which had a 1965 hit with a version of [[Johnny Kidd and the Pirates]]' "[[Shakin' All Over]]".<ref name="who" >1995 American Woman - The Story of The Guess Who by John Einarson - Quarry Press, Ontario, (ISBN 0-688-12783-5)</ref> They would eventually evolve into [[The Guess Who]], the first Canadian rock group to have a No.1 hit that reached the top on the [[Canadian Singles Chart]] and the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] at the same time, with "[[American Woman (song)|American Woman]]" in 1970.<ref name="who" /><ref>{{cite web | title= About Randy Bachman | work=colinarthur.com|url=http://www.colinarthur.com/randybachman.html|accessdate=2009-07-21}}</ref> Their success paved the way for a new wave of Canadian singer-songwriters, including [[Stan Rogers]], [[Murray McLauchlan]], [[Bruce Cockburn]] and [[Willie P. Bennett]].<ref name="Axes" />
Unlike the generation before, the late sixties American and British [[counterculture]] and [[hippie]] movements had diverted rock towards psychedelic rock, heavy metal, progressive rock and many other styles, most dominated by socially and politically incisive lyrics.<ref>San Francisco Chronicle, 18 January 1967 column, p. 27</ref> The music was an attempt to reflect upon the events of the time --- [[civil rights]], the growing unrest in America over the war in [[Vietnam]], and the rise of [[feminism]].<ref name="Axes" >Axes, Chops & Hot Licks: the Canadian rock music scene by Ritchie York, (Edmonton: Hurtig, 1971, 1979) (ISBN 0-88830-052-2)</ref> In many instances, the "message" within the song was simplistic or banal.<ref name="canrock" /> Although only two of the five original members of Steppenwolf were born in Canada ([[Jerry Edmonton]] and [[Goldy McJohn]]), the band was among the biggest in Canadian music in the 1960s and 1970s.<ref name="canrock" /> German born frontman, John Kay, would later become a [[Canadian citizen]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.steppenwolf.com/s/w/bio.html |title=JOHN KAY & STEPPENWOLF |work=www.steppenwolf.com|accessdate=2010-02-10 }}</ref> and was the only member of Steppenwolf to be inducted into the [[Canadian Music Hall of Fame]]<ref name="Music Hall">{{cite web | title= Canadian Music Hall of Fame inductees | work=The Canadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences |url=http://www.carasonline.ca/HOF_past.php|accessdate=2007-08-18}} Requires running a searches for Artist</ref> and [[Canada's Walk of Fame]].<ref name="Walkfame">{{cite web | title= Canada's Walk of Fame inductees | work=canadaswalkoffame.com|accessdate=2006-11-26 |url=http://www.canadaswalkoffame.com/inducteelist|accessdate=2010-02-10}} Requires running a searches for Artist or year</ref> Steppenwolf is most famous for the songs [[Born to Be Wild]], [[Magic Carpet Ride]] and [[The Pusher]]. Born to be Wild is the group's biggest hit, making it to #2 on the Billboard Hot 100<ref name="billboard" /> in 1968, becoming one of the [[The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll|500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll]]<ref>{{cite web | title=500 Songs That Shaped Rock and Roll|url=http://www.rockhall.com/exhibithighlights/500-songs |work= Rockhall.com|accessdate =2007-08-18 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070809183054/http://www.rockhall.com/exhibithighlights/500-songs <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-09}}</ref> by the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]],<ref>{{cite web | title= Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees | work=rockhall.com|url=http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/inductee-list/|accessdate=2007-08-18}}</ref> and becoming one of [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time]].<ref>{{cite web | title=The 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|work= rollingstone.com|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/coverstory/500songs |accessdate=2007-08-18}}</ref> Another one of the most prominent players of the late 60s and early 70s rock scene was [[Neil Young]],<ref name="albums">{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/globaltv/globalshows/et_story.html?id=981a7cd4-4a31-4c0a-a024-0ffd50445df4 |title=Neil Young, Joni Mitchell top best 100 Canadian albums|last=Harrison|first=Tom|date=18 October 2007|work=canada.com|publisher=[[Canwest News Service]]|accessdate=2010-02-10 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071022031415/http://www.canada.com/globaltv/globalshows/et_story.html?id=981a7cd4-4a31-4c0a-a024-0ffd50445df4 |archivedate = 2007-10-22}}</ref> who was a member of the folk rock band [[Buffalo Springfield]], before joining [[Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young]]. Young also recorded music with [[Crazy Horse]] throughout his solo career.<ref>{{cite web | title= Rock and Roll in the 1960s| work=Southern Methodist University|url=http://faculty.smu.edu/dsimon/change-music%2060s.html|accessdate=2008-11-26}}</ref> The song "[[Ohio (Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young song)|Ohio]]", written by Neil Young<ref>{{cite book |title=Shakey |last=McDonough |first=Jimmy |year=2002 |publisher=Anchor Books |location=New York |isbn=0-679-75096-7 |pages=345 }}</ref> and recorded with CSNY, was in response to political events of the time and has since become an America social icon of the period.<ref>{{cite book |title= The American counterculture took CSNY as its own after the song "Ohio", giving the four a status as leaders and spokesmen.|last=McDonough |first=Jimmy |year=2002 |publisher=Anchor Books |location=New York |isbn=0-679-75096-7 |pages=335 }}</ref> "Ohio" was written about the [[Kent State shootings|death of four students]] at [[Kent State University]]. The students were shot by [[Ohio National Guard]]smen during an [[anti-war protest]] on the campus in May 1970.<ref>Farber, David. Chicago â68. Chicago: [[University of Chicago Press]], 1988. pp. 3â28</ref>
===1970s=== With the introduction of the [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]]'s (CRTC) broadcast regulations in 1970, the Canadian recording industry made rock a major focus of its activity.<ref name="Act">{{cite web|url=http://oldfraser.lexi.net/publications/forum/1998/august/appendix1.html|title=Highlights in the Evolution of Canadian Content Regulations |publisher=The Fraser Institute |date= |accessdate=2009-07-24}}</ref> In 1971, the [[Canadian content]] law was passed<ref name="Canadian Rock Music Explodes" /> ensuring Canadian culture and artists weren't overrun by the American media outlets.<ref name="Act" /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/INFO_SHT/R1.htm| title=The MAPL System | accessdate=2007-11-24 | author=Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission| publisher=[[National Campus and Community Radio Association]] }}</ref> The [[Juno Award]]s began as a reader poll conducted by Canadian music industry trade magazine RPM Weekly in December 1964.<ref name="Juno Awards at The Canadian Encyclopedia" /> A similar balloting process continued until 1970 when the RPM Gold Leaf Awards, as they were then known, were changed to the Juno Awards.<ref name="Juno Awards at The Canadian Encyclopedia" /> The first Juno Award ceremony was held in 1975 and was closely related to rectifying this same concern about Canadian content.<ref name="Juno Awards at The Canadian Encyclopedia">{{cite web |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0004198 |title= Juno Awards |work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|publisher=Historica Foundation of Canada|author=McLean, Steve|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> This led to increased production and with the ground-breaking international popularity of The Guess Who and Neil Young at the end of the 1960s, opened markets outside Canada to the country's musicians.<ref name="heart" /> Moreover, success abroad usually ensured success in Canada. Led by [[Anne Murray]] and [[The Poppy Family]], the early 1970s were a golden age for Canadian music.<ref name="heart" /><ref name="Canadian Rock Music Explodes">{{cite web |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=M1ARTM0010349 |title= Canadian Rock Music Explodes |work= Article Maclean's Magazine |publisher=Historica Foundation of Canada |date=27 March 1995|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> Many performers from the late 1960s came to the forefront in the following years, among them [[The Bells (group)|The Bells]] and [[Andy Kim]] from Montreal, [[Chilliwack (band)|Chilliwack]] from [[Vancouver]], [[Five Man Electrical Band]] from [[Ottawa]], [[Lighthouse (band)|Lighthouse]] from Toronto, [[Wednesday (band)|Wednesday]] from Oshawa, and [[The Stampeders]] from [[Calgary]].<ref name="canrock" /> [[File:Rush-in-concert.jpg|right|250px|thumb|[[Rush (band)|Rush]] in concert in [[Milan]], [[Italy]], 2004|alt=Color photo of 3 musicians on a stage, in the foreground, one man is holding a guitar, while the other is holding a bass guitar, and in the background a man playing drums.]] With the introduction in the mid 70s period of rock music on [[FM broadcasting|FM]] radio stations, where it was common practice to program extended performances, musicians were no longer limited to songs of three minutes' duration as dictated by AM stations.<ref>{{cite journal | first = E. H. | last = Armstrong | title = A Method of Reducing Disturbances in Radio Signaling by a System of Frequency Modulation | journal = Proceedings of the IRE | volume = 24 | issue = 5 | pages = 689â740 | publisher = IRE | date= May 1936 | doi = 10.1109/JRPROC.1936.227383 |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> The Canadian music industry was still nascent, with little independent music media and a limited distribution infrastructure.<ref>Have Not Been the Same: the CanRock renaissance, 1985-95 by Michael Barclay, et. al. (Toronto: ECW Press, 2001) (ISBN 1-55022-475-1)</ref> The two most internationally renowned bands to arise from this industry were [[BachmanâTurner Overdrive]] and [[Rush (band)|Rush]], both featuring acclaimed managers. BachmanâTurner Overdrive's manager, [[Bruce Allen (manager)|Bruce Allen]], went on to produce [[Loverboy]] and eventually manage such major pop stars as [[Bryan Adams]] and Anne Murray.<ref name="gold" /> [[Randy Bachman]] (formerly of The Guess Who) released his new band's first album under the name [[BachmanâTurner Overdrive (1973 album)|BachmanâTurner Overdrive]] in spring 1973, which won two Juno Awards despite being largely ignored in the US. Their second album ''[[BachmanâTurner Overdrive II]]'' hit #4 in the U.S.<ref name="billboard" /> BTO II was certified gold in eight countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.superseventies.com/sw_youaintseennothinyet.html |title=You Ain't Seen Nothing Yet |work=Super Seventies RockSite! |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> It also yielded their best-remembered # 1 single, "[[Takin' Care of Business]]" written by Randy Bachman.<ref name="billboard" /> 1974's album ''[[Not Fragile]]'' went straight to the top of the charts, and the single "You Ain't Seen Nothing Yet" hit #1 in the U.S.<ref name="billboard" /> and #2 in the UK.<ref name="billboard" /> One of the largest exports to date is Rush, that boasts 25 [[music recording sales certification|gold records]] and 14 platinum (3 multi-platinum) records,<ref>{{cite web | title= RIAA gold and platinum certifications search| work=riaa.com|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH|accessdate=2007-08-18}}</ref> making them one of the best-selling rock bands in history by 2005.<ref>[http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=tblTopArt RIAA Website Top Selling Artists]. Retrieved 2010-02-10.</ref> Rush currently place third behind [[The Beatles]] and [[The Rolling Stones]] for the most consecutive gold and platinum albums by a rock band.<ref name="RIAA" /><ref>[http://www.neosoul.com/riaa/faq.html Joel Whitburn's Top Pop Albums 1955-1996 and subsequent RIAA certifications]. Retrieved 2010-02-10.</ref>

'70s" |work=allmusic (AMG Macrovision Corporation) |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> a small wave of acts emerged from all across Canada, including [[Moxy (band)|Moxy]], [[A Foot in Coldwater]] and [[Triumph (band)|Triumph]] from Toronto, [[Trooper (band)|Trooper]] from Vancouver, and [[April Wine]] from [[Halifax, Nova Scotia (former city)|Halifax]].<ref name="Axes" /> Canadian cultural critics Overdrive, Bruce Cockburn, April Wine, [[Pat Travers]] and Neil Young, remained influential and recorded some of their most popular material of all during this period, and former "The Guess Who" lead most famous disaster in the history of [[Great Lakes]] shipping.<ref name="timeline">McCall, Timothy. Retrieved 2008-10-01.</ref> Some popular francophone bands of the time included the rock group [[Beau Dommage]] from Montreal led by [[Michel Rivard]] and the progressive rock group [[Harmonium (band)|Harmonium]] also of Montreal. Artists like [[The Kings]], [[Prism (band)|Prism]], [[Crowbar (Canadian band)|Crowbar]], [[Nick Gilder]], [[Ian Thomas (Canadian musician)|Ian Thomas]], [[Goddo]], [[Harlequin (band)|Harlequin]], [[Mahogany Rush]], [[Moxy (band)|Moxy]], [[Streetheart (band)|Streetheart]], [[Max Webster]] and [[Ironhorse]] saw their greatest success during the late 70s period.<ref name="Axes" />
Many acts have had equally vital, if less remunerative careers outside the mainstream in [[punk rock]] and its derivations, generally distinguished by a tendency to extremes of one sort or another.<ref name="heart" /> Whether in instrumental intensity, lyric content, or performance style Canadian pop music evolved with the times, reflecting worldwide trends.<ref name="Axes" /> In the late 1970s, as punk rock, [[disco]], and the emerging [[New Wave music|new wave]] ruled the landscape, Canadian groups such as [[D.O.A. (band)|D.O.A.]], [[The Viletones]], [[Forgotten Rebels|The Forgotten Rebels]], [[Rough Trade (band)|Rough Trade]], [[Diodes (band)|Diodes]], [[Teenage Head (band)|Teenage Head]], [[The Demics]], [[Art Bergmann|The Young Canadians]] and [[Subhumans (Canadian band)|Subhumans]] emerged and continued in the 1980s with popular bands like [[SNFU]], [[Dayglo Abortions]] and [[Nomeansno]].<ref name="canrock" /> Rough Trade were particularly notable for their 1980 hit "[[High School Confidential (Rough Trade song)|High School Confidential]]", one of the first explicitly lesbian-themed pop songs to crack the Top 40 anywhere in the world.<ref name="billboard" />
===1980s=== Things changed course in the 1980s, the changing fast-paced culture was accompanied by an explosion in youth culture. Until the mid-1960s, little attention was paid to rock by Canadian daily newspapers except as news or novelty. With the introduction during the 1970s of the "[[Music critic|rock critic]]", coverage began to rival that of any other music.<ref name="Arts" >''The Arts in the 1970s: Cultural Closure?'' B. J. Moore-Gilbert 1994 Routledge ISBN 0-415-09906-4. Page 240</ref> The 1980s saw Canada support and promote many of its own talent in pursuit of true originality.<ref>{{cite book | title = A History of Rock Music: 1951-2000 - Page 285| work = By Piero Scaruffi ISBN 0-595-29565-7 |url = http://books.google.com/?id=04KtwVkHNv0C&pg=PA285&dq=rock+music+history+in+canada |accessdate=2010-02-10 | isbn = 9780595295654 | author1 = Scaruffi, Piero | year = 2003}}</ref> Canadian rock generally had been discouraged by market forces before the 1980s, in particular the need to conform to the taste of a Canadian audience that has had its standards and expectations formed by constant exposure to US and British acts for the prior three decades.<ref name="heart" >Heart of Gold: 30 years of Canadian pop music by Martin Melhuish, (Toronto: CBC Enterprises, 1983) (ISBN 0887841125)</ref> The popularity of [[Chilliwack (band)|Chilliwack]], for example, rose dramatically after the band turned from the experimental nature of its first few LPs to a mainstream pop style consistent with the US style. The band first hit the Top 10 charts in Canada with 1973s "Lonesome Mary",<ref name="CHUM" /> but are perhaps best remembered for three America hit songs from the 1980s "My Girl (Gone Gone Gone)", "I Believe" and "Whatcha Gonna Do".<ref name="billboard" /> Even though those three hits were their only popular singles in the US, the band has releasing over a dozen albums with [[Chilliwack (band)#Singles|23 Canadian hit singles]].<ref name="Bill Henderson 2007">{{cite web |year=2007 |url =http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=U1ARTU0000695|title = Chilliwack|publisher = [http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/ The Canadian Encyclopedia]| accessdate = 2007-08-16 | last=[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/ The Canadian Encyclopedia]}}</ref> [[Bill Henderson (Canadian singer)|Bill Henderson]], the founder of the band, was musical director for the Canadian edition of ''[[Sesame Street]]'' from 1989 to 1995. Henderson also acted as director of the Canadian Association of Recording Arts and Sciences ([[CARAS]]) and as president of the Songwriters Association of Canada ([[SOCAN]]).<ref name="Bill Henderson 2007"/>

Music videos assumed a major role in the promotion of pop rock recordings in 1980s for US exposure. Videos produced many mainstream pop-rockers that saw huge success in and outside of Canada.<ref>Denisoff, R. Serge (1991) Inside MTV New Brunswick: Transaction publishers ISBN 0-88738-864-7</ref> Success in the larger US market remained the major goal of most, if not all, post-1970 Canadian rock acts; a goal in fact reached with some greater or lesser degree of consistency by several, among them Bryan Adams, [[Aldo Nova]], [[Loverboy]], [[Saga (band)|Saga]], [[Red Rider]], [[Corey Hart (singer)|Corey Hart]], [[Alannah Myles]], [[Lee Aaron]], [[Tom Cochrane]], [[Honeymoon Suite]], [[Doug and the Slugs]] and [[Glass Tiger]].<ref name="gold" /> As well, the era produced the country [[cowpunk]] of [[k.d. lang]].<ref name="billboard" /><ref name="RPM" /> Bryan Adams would emerge as Canada's [[superstar]] of the 80s<ref>{{cite web | title= GRAMMY Award WINNERS | work=grammy.com|url=http://www.grammy.com/GRAMMY_Awards/Winners/|accessdate=2007-08-18}}</ref> having been awarded the [[Order of Canada]],<ref>{{cite web | title=The Order of Canada member list| work=nndb.com|url=http://www.nndb.com/honors/490/000032394/|accessdate=2006-11-26}}</ref> and the [[Order of British Columbia]]<ref>{{cite web|author=BC Internet Services |url=http://www.protocol.gov.bc.ca/protocol/prgs/obc/1990/1990_BAdams.htm |title=O.B.C. Biography â Bryan Adams |publisher=Protocol.gov.bc.ca |date= |accessdate=2009-07-24}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and inducted into [[Canada's Walk of Fame]] in 1998 for his contribution to popular music and his philanthropic work. Also notable is Loverboy who accumulated numerous hit songs in Canada<ref name="CHUM" /> and the United States, making four multi-platinum albums.<ref name="RIAA" /> The band's hit singles, particularly "[[Lovin' Every Minute of It (song)|Lovin' Every Minute of It]]" and "[[Working for the Weekend]]" have become hard rock staples, and are still heard on classic rock radio stations across the US and Canada. Loverboy has received five Juno Awards, Canada's highest award for music, in one year, a record that still stands today.<ref name="RIAA" /> The band would later receive an additional three Juno Awards, bringing their total to eight, which is the most received by a single group or individual except Bryan Adams.<ref name="heart" />
[[Music video]]s became more and more important as a marketing tool for Canadian bands by the mid 1980s with the debut of [[MuchMusic]] in 1984 and [[MusiquePlus]] in 1986. Now both English and French Canadian musicians had outlets to promote their music through video in Canada.<ref>[http://www.muchmusic.com/aboutus/faq/#programming What is the first video that MuchMusic aired?]. MuchMusic. Retrieved 2010-02-10</ref> The networks were not just an opportunity for artists to get their videos playedâthe networks created [[VideoFACT]], a fund to help emerging artists ''produce'' their videos. [[New Wave music|New Wave]], [[Glam Rock]] and heavy metal had become the most popular style of rock in the mid 1980s.<ref>{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=explore|id=style/d655|pure_url=yes}} |title=Heavy Metal on Allmusic "Metal enjoyed its greatest presence on the charts during the '80s, thanks to a raft of glammed-up pop-metal bands..." |work=allmusic (AMG Macrovision Corporation)|accessdate=2010-02-10 }}</ref> Acts such as [[Platinum Blonde (band)|Platinum Blonde]], [[Helix (band)|Helix]], [[Toronto (band)|Toronto]], [[Parachute Club (band)|Parachute Club]], [[The Box (band)|The Box]], [[Strange Advance]], [[Spoons (band)|Spoons]], [[Trans-X]], [[Rational Youth]], [[Men Without Hats]], [[Norman Iceberg]], [[Images in Vogue]], [[Headpins]], [[Sheriff (band)|Sheriff]], [[Frozen Ghost]], [[Teenage Head (band)|Teenage Head]], [[Idle Eyes]], [[Eight Seconds]], [[The Northern Pikes]], [[Brighton Rock (band)|Brighton Rock]] and [[Martha and the Muffins]] were along for the new Canadian music video ride.<ref name="heart" /> Although many of them, in fact, were only "[[One-hit wonders in Canada|one-hit wonders]]".(see [[One-hit wonders in Canada]])

In the late 1980s, the Canadian recording industry continued to produce popular acts such as [[Blue Rodeo]]. [[Alternative rock]] also emerged as an influential genre, with independent artists such as [[The Tragically Hip]], [[54-40]], [[Sarah McLachlan]], [[Spirit of the West]], [[The Waltons (Canadian band)|The Waltons]], [[Cowboy Junkies]], [[The Pursuit of Happiness (band)|The Pursuit of Happiness]], and [[The Grapes of Wrath (band)|The Grapes of Wrath]] all gaining their first widespread attention during this time.<ref name="RPM" /><ref name="Arts" /> Also a new wave of Canadian [[thrash metal]] bands began to rise up and earned a dedicated following like [[Anvil (band)|Anvil]], [[Razor (band)|Razor]], [[Voivod (band)|Voivod]], [[Sword (band)|Sword]], [[Exciter (band)|Exciter]] and [[Annihilator (band)|Annihilator]], Canadian metal's biggest selling artist, with sales of close to 2 million units worldwide, with [[industrial music|industrial]] bands [[Skinny Puppy]] and [[Front Line Assembly]] in the mix, as well as black/death metal band [[Blasphemy (band)|Blasphemy]].
Canada's most successful rock artists by the late 1980s have worked in a relatively generic, mainstream pop rock style of the day. Some from the 70s, 80s and 90s, may be ascribed to more specific substyles like [[Colin James]], [[David Wilcox (Canadian musician)|David Wilcox]] and [[Jeff Healey]] to blues-rock (see [[Canadian blues]]). With [[Stompin' Tom Connors]], [[Great Big Sea]] and [[Ashley MacIsaac]] to folk rock, that saw the start for both styles, a very large following all across Canada.<ref name="Arts" /><ref>[http://stonyplainrecords.com/Web/about_us.asp Stony Plain Records: Canada's Roots, Rock, Country, Folk & Blues Label]. Retrieved 2010-02-10</ref> Most notable would be Stompin' Tom Connors who typically writes about Canadian lore and history , some of Connors' better-known songs include [[Big Joe Mufferaw]], [[Black Donnellys|The Black Donnellys]], [[Reesor Siding Strike of 1963|Reesor Crossing Tragedy]], [[Sudbury Saturday Night]] and [[The Hockey Song]] (aka "The Good Old Hockey Game"), that is frequently played over sound systems at [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) games in both Canada and the United States.<ref>Connors, Stompin' Tom (1995). Just as artists from the 1970s competed with disco, artists from the 1990s were competing with [[Canadian hip hop]] and American hip hop on the Video and Radio charts.<ref>Alan Light; et al. (October 1999). The Vibe History of Hip Hop. Three Rivers Press. pp. 432. (ISBN 0-609-80503-7)</ref> Glam metal and [[arena rock]] had lost its position as Hip hop, alternative rock and [[grunge]] became the new sound of the next generation. Canadian publications devoted to Canadian rock and pop music, either exclusively or in tandem with more general editorial content directed to young readers, was expanding rapidly in the 90s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ir.lib.sfu.ca/bitstream/1892/4011/1/etd2656.pdf |title=WRITERS-IN-RESIDENCE IN CANADA, 1965-2000 |work=Earle, Nancy Elizabeth LeDrew Pg. 171(Thesis (Ph.D.) - Department of English-[[Simon Fraser University]])|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> It was a decade of incredible nationalism, at least as far as English-Canadian music was concerned.<ref>The Canadian encyclopedia By James H. ===2000s=== The early first decade of the 21st century were dominated by [[post-grunge]] and continued to see the expansion of alternative rock, pop-punk, hard rock, and indie rock both artistically and commercially. The main musical phenomenon was the emergence of a new generation of singer songwriters that were the direct consequence of the previous generation's intellectual ambitions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scaruffi.com/history/cpt77.html |title=The History of Rock Music: The 2000s |work=piero scaruffi's music review |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> The biggest factor that has contributed to the resurgence of rock music in the first decade of the 21st century is the rise of paid [[Music download|digital downloads]].<ref>[http://www.ibisworld.com/pressrelease/pressrelease.aspx?prid=127: June 2008, The Tables Have Turned: Rock Stars â Not Record Labels â Cashing In On Digital Revolution], ''IBISWorld''. Retrieved 2010-02-10.</ref> The vast majority of songs bought on paid download sites are singles bought from full albums; songs that are bought on a song-by-song basis off artist's albums are considered sales of singles, even though they have no official single for purchase. The boom of [[independent music]] at the turn of the millennium changed the dynamics of the music industry. At about the same time, the [[CD]] (cheap to manufacture) replaced the [[vinyl album]] and [[Compact Cassette|cassette tapes]] (expensive to manufacture).<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-10705268.html End of track. (the vinyl record is meeting its demise in music recording industry) The Economist (US) | May 11, 1991]. Retrieved 2010-02-10.</ref> Shortly thereafter, the [[Internet]] allowed musicians to directly distribute their music, thus bypassing the selection of the old-fashioned "[[record label]]".<ref name=Millard>Millard, Andre, [http://books.google.com/books?id=gd2b0M2fDckC&pg=PA353&dq=record+playing+time&lr=&as_brr=3&sig=7-b5dyw-qWHnsJbSCQUgg6bAN7I#PPA58,M1 America on Record: A History of Recorded Sound]. [[Cambridge University Press]], 1995, ISBN 0-521-47556-2. [[Google Books]]. Retrieved 2010-02-10</ref> Canada's music industry has suffered as a result of the challenging times for the better part of the last decade. The drop in annual sales between 1999 - the year that [[Napster]]'s unauthorized [[peer-to-peer]] file sharing service launched - and the end of 2004 was $465 million.<ref name="President">{{cite web |url=http://www.cria.ca/about.php |work= Canadian Recording Industry Association |title=(CRIA)President's Message|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> Canada in 2008 joined 50 other nations in updating its [[Copyright Act of Canada|Copyright Act]], and in doing so aims to allow artists and others to seek compensation for their work, no matter how it is distributed.<ref name="President" /> In 2010 Canada introduced new copyright legislation.<ref name=digital/> The amended law makes hacking digital locks illegal, but enshrine into law the ability of purchasers to record and copy music from a CD to portable devices.<ref name=digital>{{cite web|title=Canada announces new copyright law for digital age |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iI9pXzLLcyvoJCMSwKgUvHEbH3HA |publisher=Google News|year=2010|accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref>

[[File:Rock en Seine 2007, The Arcade Fire.jpg|right|240px|thumb| [[Arcade Fire]] in Paris, France 2007.]] The end of the decade was notable for a surprising number of ambitious indie rock albums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blender.com/guide/articles.aspx?ID=2974 |title=The 100 Greatest Indie Rock Albums Ever |accessdate=2008-02-08 |author=Jon Dolan, Josh Eells, Will Hermes, Jonah Weiner, Douglas Wolk |month=December | year=2007 |work=[[Blender Magazine|Blender]]|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> The Canadian indie rock scene has been the focus of national and international attention in many publications, such as ''[[Spin magazine|Spin]]'', ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[Under the Radar (magazine)|Under the Radar]]'', as well the Canadian edition of ''[[Time Magazine]]''. It can be difficult for an indie group to break through in Canada as there is no nationwide rock station. On the other hand, although rock bands may get some exposure from outlets such as MuchMusic and [[CBC Radio 3]], bands must largely rely on building an audience city by city, as each commercial radio station makes its playlist decisions independently. Similarly, it is more difficult to ''travel'' nationwide as well due to the vast size, creating regional communities that revolve around major music scenes in cities like Winnipeg, Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal or Halifax, each with a handful of offshoot suburban town scenes that produce the next wave of fresh bands. Most notable is [[Arcade Fire]], who have won numerous awards, including the 2011 [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Grammy for Album of the Year]], the 2011 [[Juno Award for Album of the Year]], and the 2011 [[Brit Award]] for Best International Album for their third studio album, ''[[The Suburbs (Arcade Fire album)|The Suburbs]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/13/AR2011021303447.html?hpid=top |title=Esperanza Spalding, Arcade Fire top a night of upsets at 2011 Grammys |first=Chris |last=Richards |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
